para: Internally, &SCons; represents all of the files and directories it knows about as &Nodes;. These internal objects (not object files) can be used in a variety of ways to make your &SConscript; files portable and easy to read.

section.title: Builder Methods Return Lists of Target Nodes
section.para: All builder methods return a list of &Node; objects that identify the target file or files that will be built. These returned &Nodes; can be passed as arguments to other builder methods.

For example, suppose that we want to build the two object files that make up a program with different options. This would mean calling the &b-link-Object; builder once for each object file, specifying the desired options:
One way to combine these object files into the resulting program would be to call the &b-link-Program; builder with the names of the object files listed as sources:

The problem with specifying the names as strings is that our &SConstruct; file is no longer portable across operating systems. It won't, for example, work on Windows because the object files there would be named &hello_obj; and &goodbye_obj;, not &hello_o; and &goodbye_o;.
A better solution is to assign the lists of targets returned by the calls to the &b-Object; builder to variables, which we can then concatenate in our call to the &b-Program; builder:
section.programlisting: hello_list = Object('hello.c', CCFLAGS='-DHELLO') goodbye_list = Object('goodbye.c', CCFLAGS='-DGOODBYE') Program(hello_list + goodbye_list)
section.para: This makes our &SConstruct; file portable again, the build output on Linux looking like:
section.screen: % scons -Q cc -o goodbye.o -c -DGOODBYE goodbye.c cc -o hello.o -c -DHELLO hello.c cc -o hello hello.o goodbye.o

C:\>scons -Q
scons: warning: No installed VCs File "<stdin>", line 67, in __call__
scons: warning: No version of Visual Studio compiler found - C/C++ compilers most likely not set correctly File "<stdin>", line 67, in __call__ cl /Fogoodbye.obj /c goodbye.c -DGOODBYE cl /Fohello.obj /c hello.c -DHELLO link /nologo /OUT:hello.exe hello.obj goodbye.obj
section.para: We'll see examples of using the list of nodes returned by builder methods throughout the rest of this guide.

section.title: Explicitly Creating File and Directory Nodes
section.para: It's worth mentioning here that &SCons; maintains a clear distinction between Nodes that represent files and Nodes that represent directories. &SCons; supports &File; and &Dir; functions that, respectively, return a file or directory Node:
section.programlisting:
hello_c = File('hello.c') Program(hello_c)
classes = Dir('classes') Java(classes, 'src')
section.para: Normally, you don't need to call &File; or &Dir; directly, because calling a builder method automatically treats strings as the names of files or directories, and translates them into the Node objects for you. The &File; and &Dir; functions can come in handy in situations where you need to explicitly instruct &SCons; about the type of Node being passed to a builder or other function, or unambiguously refer to a specific file in a directory tree.

There are also times when you may need to refer to an entry in a file system without knowing in advance whether it's a file or a directory. For those situations, &SCons; also supports an &Entry; function, which returns a Node that can represent either a file or a directory.
The returned xyzzy Node will be turned into a file or directory Node the first time it is used by a builder method or other function that requires one vs. the other.

section.title: Printing &Node; File Names
section.para: One of the most common things you can do with a Node is use it to print the file name that the node represents. Keep in mind, though, that because the object returned by a builder call is a list of Nodes, you must use Python subscripts to fetch individual Nodes from the list. For example, the following &SConstruct; file:
section.programlisting:
hello_c = File('hello.c') Program(hello_c)
classes = Dir('classes') Java(classes, 'src')
object_list = Object('hello.c') program_list = Program(object_list) print "The object file is:", object_list[0] print "The program file is:", program_list[0]
section.para: Would print the following file names on a POSIX system:
section.screen: % scons -Q The object file is: hello.o The program file is: hello cc -o hello.o -c hello.c cc -o hello hello.o
section.para: And the following file names on a Windows system:
section.screen:
C:\>scons -Q
scons: warning: No installed VCs File "<stdin>", line 67, in __call__
scons: warning: No version of Visual Studio compiler found - C/C++ compilers most likely not set correctly File "<stdin>", line 67, in __call__ The object file is: hello.obj The program file is: hello.exe cl /Fohello.obj /c hello.c /nologo link /nologo /OUT:hello.exe hello.obj
section.para: Note that in the above example, the object_list[0] extracts an actual Node object from the list, and the Python print statement converts the object to a string for printing.

section.title: Using a &Node;'s File Name as a String
section.para: Printing a &Node;'s name as described in the previous section works because the string representation of a &Node; object is the name of the file. If you want to do something other than print the name of the file, you can fetch it by using the builtin Python &str; function. For example, if you want to use the Python os.path.exists to figure out whether a file exists while the &SConstruct; file is being read and executed, you can fetch the string as follows:
section.programlisting: import os.path program_list = Program('hello.c') program_name = str(program_list[0]) if not os.path.exists(program_name): print program_name, "does not exist!"
section.para: Which executes as follows on a POSIX system:
section.screen: % scons -Q hello does not exist! cc -o hello.o -c hello.c cc -o hello hello.o
